awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Antarctic Airborne ElectroMagnetics (ANTAEM) - Revealing Subsurface Water in Coastal Antarctica
awd_abstract_narration:
In Antarctica, millions of years of freezing have led to the development of hundreds of meters of thick permafrost (i.e., frozen ground). Recent research demonstrated that this slow freezing has trapped and concentrated water into local and regional briny aquifers, many times more salty than seawater. Because salt depresses the freezing point of water, these saline brines are able to persist as liquid water at temperatures well below the normal freezing point of freshwater. Such unusual groundwater systems may support microbial life, supply nutrients to coastal ocean and ice-covered lakes, and influence motion of glaciers. These briny aquifers also represent potential terrestrial analogs for deep life habitats on other planets, such as Mars, and provide a testing ground for the search for extraterrestrial water. Whereas much effort has been invested in understanding the physics, chemistry, and biology of surface and near-surface waters in cold polar regions, it has been comparably difficult to investigate deep subsurface aquifers in such settings. Airborne ElectroMagnetics (AEM) subsurface imaging provides an efficient way for mapping salty groundwater. An international collaboration with the University of Aarhus in Denmark will enable knowledge and skill transfer in AEM techniques that will enhance US polar research capabilities and provide US undergraduates and graduate students with unique training experiences. This project will survey over 1000 km2 of ocean and land near McMurdo Station in Antarctica, and will reveal if cold polar deserts hide a subsurface pool of liquid water. This will have significant implications for understanding cold polar glaciers, ice-covered lakes, frozen ground, and polar microbiology as well as for predictions of their response to future change. Improvements in permafrost mapping techniques and understanding of permafrost and of underlying groundwaters will benefit human use of high polar regions in the Antarctic and the Arctic.

The project will provide the first integrative system-scale overview of subsurface water distribution and hydrological connectivity in a partly ice-free coastal region of Antarctica, the McMurdo Dry Valleys. Liquid water is relatively scarce in this environment but plays an outsized role by influencing, and integrating, biological, biogeochemical, glaciological, and geological processes. Whereas surface hydrology and its role in ecosystem processes has been thoroughly studied over the last several decades, it has been difficult to map out and characterize subsurface water reservoirs and to understand their interactions with regional lakes, glaciers, and coastal waters. The proposed project builds on the "proof-of-concept" use of AEM technology in 2011. Improvements in sensor and data processing capabilities will result in about double the depth of penetration of the subsurface during the new data collection when compared to the 2011 proof-of-concept survey, which reached depths of 300-400m. The first field season will focus on collecting deep soundings with a ground-based system in key locations where: (i) independent constraints on subsurface structure exist from past drilling projects, and (ii) the 2011 resistivity dataset indicates the need for deeper penetration and high signal-to-noise ratios achievable only with a ground-based system. The regional airborne survey will take place during the second field season and will yield subsurface electrical resistivity data from across several valleys of different sizes and different ice cover fractions.

por.por_cntn:
The project used a novel application of remote sensing technology to peer into the soil and in sediments buried deep below glaciers to search for liquid water and brines (salty water) that might provide habitats for microbes adapted to some of the most extreme conditions on Earth. We used a helicopter borne electromagnetic antenna (ANTAEM) to survey large areas of the coastal region of Antarctica in the McMurdo Dry Valleys. The antenna sends a strong magnetic signal deep below the surface. The signal reflected to a sensor on the helicopter can be analyzed to make three-dimensional maps of soil water, buried ice, and buried unfrozen salty groundwater (brines) below glaciers and the Antarctic Ice Sheet to depths of 1,000 feet.

The McMurdo Dry Valleys are largely snow free and contain ice covered lakes, streams that briefly flow in summer, and mountain glaciers that connect to the vast Antarctic Ice Sheet. They are among the coldest and driest environments on Earth and are studied in part as the place on Earth most like Mars. Liquid water is required by all life on Earth. Determining where water habitats exist in the near surface and deep beneath the ice in Antarctica may provide insight on potential habitats suitable for life on other worlds, and better define the range of environmental extremes under which microbes live and function on our planet.

This ANTAEM subproject examined the distribution of liquid water in the upper 15 feet of soil in Taylor Valley, Antarctica and the chemistry of Don Juan Pond in adjacent Wright Valley, a body of water so salty that it never freezes even under the extreme temperatures of the Antarctic winter. We mapped the distribution of soil water in Taylor Valley using ANTAEM and related this to the water content, elevation, and salinity of soils collected near lakes and extending to the upper elevations of Taylor Valley. In Don Juan Pond, we measure the salinity and the chemical composition of surface liquid brine down into the brine saturated sediments to a depth of one foot.

Surface soil water was highest in the lower elevation locations where soils had higher amounts of very fine particles (clays) and moderate salinity.  In locations where ANTAEM aerial survey coverage overlapped in 2011 and 2018, patterns of soil moisture and depth to frozen soil were detected and could be related to seasonal differences in temperature. The ANTAEM method provided large scale maps of surface soil conditions across Taylor Valley, the most intensively studied area of continental Antarctica. This information will be useful to understand how the dry valleys might respond to climate change and how the distribution of suitable habitats for soil life may shift in location and with season as climate warms.

The collaborating Mikucki lab group at the University of Tennessee Knoxville has isolated microbes from the highly saline brines associated with the Don Juan Pond (DJP) ecosystem. Culturable (living) microbial cells are present in brines within the pond sediment, but not in the overlying surface brine. Measurements of salinity and chemistry experienced by microbes in the brine found between sediment particles beneath the overlying brine show these habitats are comparable chemical environments. This suggests that make up of the sediments (minerals) and the sizes of sediment particles along with other chemical factors in the sediment (perhaps organic matter absorbed to the surfaces of sediment particles) may be necessary to provide a suitable habitat for microbes, whereas the surface liquid brine of similar chemistry may not. This finding shows that many factors may interact between liquid brines and brine saturated sediments to determine where life may exist in saline polar desert ponds and perhaps in saline brines deep beneath glaciers and the ice sheet.

The results of this research will have significant implications for understanding cold polar glaciers, ice-covered lakes, frozen ground, and polar microbiology as well as for predictions of their response to future change.
